content.description:
In Mayli Vang’s poem “Relations,” published in 2000, the speaker describes her family. Read the poem carefully. Then, write a paragraph in which you make a defensible claim regarding how Vang uses contrasts to convey the complex relationships among the members of the speaker’s family. In your paragraph, you should incorporate at least one piece of evidence from the text to support your claim.

In your response you should do the following:

Respond to the prompt with a claim that presents a defensible interpretation.

Select and use evidence to support your interpretation.

Explain how the evidence supports your interpretation.

Use appropriate grammar and punctuation in communicating your your argument.

Relations

Father left when I was five

he dwells among the dead

in a land foreign to my imagination.

Remnants of his existence:

5A black-and-white wallet-size picture,

a faded yellow shirt.

Mother keeps to the living room

sewing her life into cloth

too fearful to confront the world.

10She has sewn forty patches of:

Make New Friends and Keep the Old

as Silver, the New Ones Gold.

Sister inhabits the kitchen

cooking her dreams away

15the perfect daughter.

Wednesday’s menu for dinner:

rice, chicken boiled with bitter melon,

baby bok with garlic and pork.

Brother is nowhere to be found

20out roaming the world he will inherit

he’s a man, okay.

Friday afternoon: a police officer

escorts him home for stealing

a Nestlé crunch bar at J. J. Newberry’s.1a chain of discount stores

25I am in my room where thoughts

are locked in books and dreams

are stored on shelves. I’m still young

I keep telling myself.

2:30 A.M.: I am still writing

30mother hits me on the head with my journal

can you eat straight A’s?

She wants to know.
"Relations," Mayli Vang, New Rivers Press, 2000.
